page_6_img_1.png.title: New Chemical Dopant and Counterion Mechanism for Organic Electrochemical Transistors and Organic Mixed Ionic–Electronic Conductors
page_6_img_1.png.full_caption: Figure 3. GIWAXS data for the pristine pNDTI-TT system (i.e., 0 mol% TBA-OH) thin film, measured when a) not exposed to electrolyte and b) after exposure to 0.1 M NaCl electrolyte for 3 days. GIWAXS data for the best-performing pNDTI-TT:TBA-OH (400 mol%) TBA-OH measured when c) not exposed to electrolyte and d) after exposing to 0.1 M NaCl electrolyte for 3 days.

page_7_img_1.png.title: New Chemical Dopant and Counterion Mechanism for Organic Electrochemical Transistors and Organic Mixed Ionic–Electronic Conductors
page_7_img_1.png.full_caption: Figure 4. Characteristics of doped pNDIT-TT oligomer obtained by DFT calculations: a) chain geometry of neutral state P, reduced state without counterion P−, and reduced state with counterion [TBA+·P−]; b) polaron charge distribution for P− and [TBA+·P−]; c) optical absorption spectrum for P, P−, and [TBA+·P−], the position of the polaron peak shown by the arrow reflects how strongly bound the TBA+ counterion relative to pNDIT-TT oligomer (chains truncated for clarity); the associated polaron charge distributions are shown in (a) and optical absorption spectra in (f). We note that, although there is no substantial, visible difference in the polaron delocalization, the shape of the polaron charge distribution is noticeably different, as influenced by the position of the counterion relative to the pNDIT-TT unit where the polaron is centered, as shown in (e).

captions.label: a
captions.description: chain geometry of neutral state P, reduced state without counterion P−, and reduced state with counterion [TBA+·P−]

captions.label: b
captions.description: polaron charge distribution for P− and [TBA+·P−]

captions.label: c
captions.description: optical absorption spectrum for P, P−, and [TBA+·P−], the position of the polaron peak shown by the arrow reflects how strongly bound the TBA+ counterion relative to pNDIT-TT oligomer (chains truncated for clarity); the associated polaron charge distributions are shown in (a) and optical absorption spectra in (f). We note that, although there is no substantial, visible difference in the polaron delocalization, the shape of the polaron charge distribution is noticeably different, as influenced by the position of the counterion relative to the pNDIT-TT unit where the polaron is centered, as shown in (e).
